<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_set_enable:
```c
static void metal_softirq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *cntr,
				     int irq, unsigned int enable)
{
	if (irq < cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= (cntr->irq_base + cntr->irq_num)) {
		return;
	}

	irq -= cntr->irq_base;
	if (enable ==  METAL_IRQ_ENABLE) {
		atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 1);
	} else {
		atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 0);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_softirq_set_enable:

...
#define METAL_IRQ_ENABLE 1U
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 0);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the statement atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 0) performs an atomic store and does not call metal_softirq_set_enable. There is no direct or indirect call from metal_softirq_set_enable to itself in the provided code. (A hypothetical violation could occur only if atomic_store or some function it calls ended up calling metal_softirq_set_enable, creating indirect recursion — no evidence of that here.)
